basics.name: Haleigh Schwartz
basics.label: Data Scientist | Healthcare Analyst | Runner
basics.summary: Passionate about caring holistically for the underserved, working towards more sustainable healthcare, and learning endlessly to answer some of medicine's most pressing questions.

work.name: Main Street Family Medicine, PLLC
work.summary: At our small clinic, we all wear many hats. As the office manager, I extract and analyze our healthcare and company data, optimize processes for our staff, continually keep up to date with best practices in medicine and business, manage our website, and solve the many, unique problems that present themselves each day.

work.name: Main Street Family Medicine, PLLC
work.summary:
As an Administrative Assistant, my work ranges from routine tasks such as billing and payroll to more creative and innovative projects like creating efficient processes for the staff, managing the website, and discovering various business solutions with data analysis and visualization. 

In my MA role, I assist with phlebotomy, in-office procedures, scheduling, navigating patients through the maze that is our complex healthcare system, and other miscellaneous needs around the office.

work.name: Oregon Health & Science University
work.summary: I conducted experiments, analyzed my experimental data, and designed figures for two upcoming publications.

work.name: EvergreenHealth
work.summary: I aided the CT techs in the Emergency Department by releasing orders, checking patients' labs to ensure their safety during the scan, going over consent forms with patients, answering phone calls, and restocking supplies.

work.name: University of Washington
work.summary: Through my involvement in the University of Washington’s (UW) Neurological Surgery Summer Student Program, I was asked to write for Grey Matters, an UW undergraduate neuroscience journal. I researched and wrote an article on the neurological basis of the phenomenon of giftedness, which was published in the spring of 2020.

work.name: University of Washington
work.summary: I completed neuroscience research at the Allen Institute for Brain Science and contributed to furthering our understanding of the basal ganglia. I observed various neurological surgeries and went on rounds with the Neurosurgery Department at Harborview Medical Center.

work.name: Northwest University
work.summary: I increased students' comprehension of college-level chemistry and physics courses and helped them develop skills necessary for furthering their learning.

work.name: Northwest University
work.summary: I researched the Murine Herpesvirus’ effects on animal cells’ metabolism and ways to kill the virus without harming the cells for my professor, Dr. Tracie Delgado. From this work, "Rewiring of the host cell metabolome and lipidome during lytic gammaherpesvirus infection is essential for infectious virus production" by Clark & Delgado, 2023, was published.

work.name: Logan Health
work.summary: I completed a summer internship at KRH where I observed in many different departments ranging from the pathology lab to the NICU to interventional radiology.

volunteer.position: Leaders Save Lives: Blood Drive Host
volunteer.summary: One summer, I assisted the American Red Cross by hosting drives, recruiting donors, and running the check-in desk at drives.

For a semester, I volunteered at Dr. Bim Makinde's clinic, where I prepped rooms for patients and procedures, observed as he worked with patients, and helped with secretarial work. My work allowed Dr. Makinde to spend more time with patients, complete his practice more efficiently, and keep his business organized. I also helped his patients feel comfortable, welcome, and informed about any questions they had. Being apart of Dr. Makinde's private practice exposed me to the business side of medicine and, as a cross country and track runner for my college, taught me a lot about injury prevention and treatment options for athletes.

awards.title: Presidential Scholar
awards.summary: I won Northwest University's Presidential Scholarship Competition during my senior year of high school, which granted me a full-tuition scholarship for eight consecutive semesters at Northwest.
